content.raw:
I've added it to the sdformat readme in https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/514/readme-clarify-that-the-parser-is-named/diff

I've added it to the sdformat readme in https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/514/readme-clarify-that-the-parser-is-named/diff

it's already on sdformat.org/spec: "The SDF version shown in the dropdown above defines the specification version. This version number may be different from the release version of libsdformat, which contains the C++ library used to parse SDF files."

content.raw: that's a good question; both the spec and the osrf reference parser implementation are stored in the same repository named `sdformat`. I would propose using `libsdformat` to refer to the reference parser and either sdf or SDFormat to refer to the specification.
content.html: that's a good question; both the spec and the osrf reference parser implementation are stored in the same repository named sdformat. I would propose using libsdformat to refer to the reference parser and either sdf or SDFormat to refer to the specification.

content.raw:
Rather than explain in prose after you introduce the example, can you explain inline with comments, directly next to the offending line?

e.g.

 `<link name="link"/>  <!-- INVALID: Same name as sibiling "link"! -->`

```
<link name="link1">
  <collision name="collision">...</collision>
</link>
<link name="link2">
  <collision name="collision">...</collision>  <!-- VALID -->
</link>
```
content.html:
Rather than explain in prose after you introduce the example, can you explain inline with comments, directly next to the offending line?

e.g.

<link name="link"/> <!-- INVALID: Same name as sibiling "link"! -->

<link name="link1">
  <collision name="collision">...</collision>
</link>
<link name="link2">
  <collision name="collision">...</collision>  <!-- VALID -->
</link>

content.raw: No, that example is not as confusing because it doesn't explicitly state that the two models are equivalent. It might cause some confusion since the pictures are similar and the URDF example comes right after the SDF example. It might be good to mention somewhere that in order to create an SDF model that is equivalent to a URDF model, all joints should have `<pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>`. We could also use the example to show that changing the joint pose so it is different from the child link pose is only possible in SDF.
content.html: No, that example is not as confusing because it doesn't explicitly state that the two models are equivalent. It might cause some confusion since the pictures are similar and the URDF example comes right after the SDF example. It might be good to mention somewhere that in order to create an SDF model that is equivalent to a URDF model, all joints should have <pose>0 0 0 0 0 0</pose>. We could also use the example to show that changing the joint pose so it is different from the child link pose is only possible in SDF.

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw:
My suggestion would be to create another example to demonstrate how the joint frame is defined relative to the child link. If you are saying the link frames are indeed in the middle of the ellipses, then the URDF and SDF are not equivalent. But this example is trying to demonstrate how we get equivalent representations in the two formats. 

In other words, if I run `gz sdf -p` on the URDF file, the output SDF file should have the joint and the link frames collocated (and it does). I was working out this example in Rviz and Gazebo to check the two:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0"?>
<robot name="testrobot" xmlns:xacro="http://www.ros.org/wiki/xacro">
  <link name="link1">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 0' xyz='0.1 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link2"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link2">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint2" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 1.5707963267948966' xyz='0 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link3"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link3">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint3" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 -1.5707963267948966' xyz='0.2 0 0'/>
    <parent link="link3"/>
    <child link="link4"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link4">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>
</robot>
```

And here is equivalent SDF (using `gz sdf`). Notice that the joint tags don't have a `<pose>` element.

```
<sdf version='1.6'>
  <model name='testrobot'>
    <link name='link1'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <link name='link2'>
      <pose frame=''>0.1 0.2 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint1' type='revolute'>
      <child>link2</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link3'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.2 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint2' type='revolute'>
      <child>link3</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link4'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.4 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint3' type='revolute'>
      <child>link4</child>
      <parent>link3</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>
```
content.html:
My suggestion would be to create another example to demonstrate how the joint frame is defined relative to the child link. If you are saying the link frames are indeed in the middle of the ellipses, then the URDF and SDF are not equivalent. But this example is trying to demonstrate how we get equivalent representations in the two formats.

In other words, if I run gz sdf -p on the URDF file, the output SDF file should have the joint and the link frames collocated (and it does). I was working out this example in Rviz and Gazebo to check the two:

<?xml version="1.0"?>
<robot name="testrobot" xmlns:xacro="http://www.ros.org/wiki/xacro">
  <link name="link1">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint1" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 0' xyz='0.1 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link2"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link2">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint2" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 1.5707963267948966' xyz='0 0.2 0'/>
    <parent link="link1"/>
    <child link="link3"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link3">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>

  <joint name="joint3" type="revolute">
    <origin rpy='0 0 -1.5707963267948966' xyz='0.2 0 0'/>
    <parent link="link3"/>
    <child link="link4"/>
    <axis xyz="0 0 1"/>
    <limit lower="-3.14" upper="3.14" effort="1000" velocity="5"/>
  </joint>
  <link name="link4">
    <inertial>
      <mass value="1"/>
    </inertial>
  </link>
</robot>

And here is equivalent SDF (using gz sdf). Notice that the joint tags don't have a <pose> element.

<sdf version='1.6'>
  <model name='testrobot'>
    <link name='link1'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <link name='link2'>
      <pose frame=''>0.1 0.2 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint1' type='revolute'>
      <child>link2</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link3'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.2 0 0 -0 1.5708</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint2' type='revolute'>
      <child>link3</child>
      <parent>link1</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
    <link name='link4'>
      <pose frame=''>0 0.4 0 0 -0 0</pose>
      <inertial>
        <pose frame=''>0 0 0 0 -0 0</pose>
        <mass>1</mass>
        <inertia>
          <ixx>0</ixx>
          <ixy>0</ixy>
          <ixz>0</ixz>
          <iyy>0</iyy>
          <iyz>0</iyz>
          <izz>0</izz>
        </inertia>
      </inertial>
    </link>
    <joint name='joint3' type='revolute'>
      <child>link4</child>
      <parent>link3</parent>
      <axis>
        <xyz>0 0 1</xyz>
        <limit>
          <lower>-3.14</lower>
          <upper>3.14</upper>
          <effort>1000</effort>
          <velocity>5</velocity>
        </limit>
        <dynamics>
          <spring_reference>0</spring_reference>
          <spring_stiffness>0</spring_stiffness>
        </dynamics>
        <use_parent_model_frame>1</use_parent_model_frame>
      </axis>
    </joint>
  </model>
</sdf>

content.raw:
I agree that it may be confusing in its current state, but I want to be able to show visually how the frames are defined, and it's hard to see that if the child link and joint frames are collocated.

I'd rather keep the figures like this but add some explanatory text about why they are different. How does that sound?
content.html:
I agree that it may be confusing in its current state, but I want to be able to show visually how the frames are defined, and it's hard to see that if the child link and joint frames are collocated.

I'd rather keep the figures like this but add some explanatory text about why they are different. How does that sound?

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

update.description: This tutorial will eventually include proposals for the semantics of describing pose frames, but I started with a description of existing legacy behavior, and it was getting decently long, so I thought I would submit it for review first before starting with proposals for new behavior.
update.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

pull_request.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

pullrequest.title: Pose frame semantics: describe legacy behavior

content.raw: I understand this figure is showing that joint poses are defined relative to their child links. But I am concerned that it might add some confusion as readers compare this diagram with the URDF diagram. The red arrows point to the "middle" of the link ellipses suggesting that the link frame is located there. This makes it look different from the URDF figure in which the link frames are coincident with the joint frames. If the URDF and SDF are supposed to be equivalent, shouldn't the location of the link and joint frames be equivalent as well?
content.html: I understand this figure is showing that joint poses are defined relative to their child links. But I am concerned that it might add some confusion as readers compare this diagram with the URDF diagram. The red arrows point to the "middle" of the link ellipses suggesting that the link frame is located there. This makes it look different from the URDF figure in which the link frames are coincident with the joint frames. If the URDF and SDF are supposed to be equivalent, shouldn't the location of the link and joint frames be equivalent as well?

content.raw:
Yup!  

\(But, uh, to nitpick, `from` and `to` but are kinda coupled to `X_AB` as a transform / operator and less as a pose... Usually something less coupling like `A` \+ `B` are safer for examples.\)
content.html:
Yup!

(But, uh, to nitpick, from and to but are kinda coupled to X_AB as a transform / operator and less as a pose... Usually something less coupling like A + B are safer for examples.)
